nodes.bodyText: @andreoss this class should be removed too as discussed in the ticket
@andreoss this class should be removed too as discussed in the ticket
@andreoss there is no need for wrapping that into Synced anymore since it is evaluated in the constructor
@andreoss what is the problem with this test?
@victornoel This test (and the one above) checks either map is lazily created or not, thus it's removed
@andreoss ok, anyway, those tests are so strange that even if they had sense they would be unmaintainable ^^ thx :)
@andreoss instead of using a Scalar based constructor, I think it would make more sense to follow the same pattern as in ListOf and SetOf.
@andreoss here please replace all of this by just wrapping the map into Collections.synchronizedMap as with list.Synced
@andreoss normally you don't need to go through MapOf, the stream.collect returns a Map that can be passed directly to super. Right?
@andreoss what is the Scalar for? If we want to create a map from an existing one, then let's just take a map in the constructor. You can then use putAll to add all the elements of the original map.
@andreoss can't we manage to avoid creating an intermediate list just to iterate over it in MapOf? I'm not very clear about what streams provide us for that though...
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -42,11 +42,12 @@
      */
     @SafeVarargs
     public Merged(final Map<K, V>... maps) {
-        super(() -> new MapOf<>(
-            new ListOf<>(maps)
-                .stream()
-                .flatMap(map -> map.entrySet().stream())
-                .collect(Collectors.toList())
+        super(
+            new MapOf<>(
+                new ListOf<>(maps)
+                    .stream()
+                    .flatMap(map -> map.entrySet().stream())
+                    .collect(Collectors.toList())

nodes.bodyText: @andreoss well actually, this is out of scope of this PR, let's forget about it, I will create an issue.
